column6: the sport of moving on your feet at a speed faster than walking
column7: I go running three times a week.^running shoes
column8: My hobbies are reading and running. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

column6: If you have or take a shower, you wash your whole body while standing under a flow of water.
column7: I got up, had a shower and got dressed.
column8: I have to wake up [at] 7.30 AM. I run to the bathroom [to] take a shower. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

column6: confidence about yourself and the situation that you are in
column7: the security of a long-term relationship
column8: One is the security of having your mom around all the time. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

column6: A sophisticated machine or system is very advanced and works in a clever way.
column7: I think a more sophisticated approach is needed to solve this problem.^These are among the most sophisticated weapons in the world.
column8: These days we can use [a] computer, television [or other] sophisticated equipment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

column6: used when you are correcting someone, disagreeing with someone, or saying no to a request
column7: Actually, Gavin, it was Tuesday of last week, not Wednesday.^"You didn't tell me about needing the car." "Actually, I did."^"Do you mind if I smoke?" "Actually, I'd rather you didn't."
column8: Actually, TORRENTS was [the] second group [at the festival]. I think you probably missed the first performance [in] which KING CUP sang. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

column6: If a disease, chemical, etc. attacks someone or something, it damages them.
column7: The virus attacks the central nervous system.
column8: There is a myriad of diseases that attack the less protected. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

column6: not yet familiar or experienced
column7: I'm new to the area.^She's new to the job so you can't expect her to know everything yet.^New staff are given training.
column8: I met a guy called Marc [who] is pretty cool. He is also new to the club. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

column6: to do something in order to discover if something is safe, works correctly, etc.
column7: None of our products are tested on animals.
column8: Before we can use a certain med[i]cine, hairspray, make-up, [etc,] it might have been tested on animals to see [what] their reaction is. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

column6: to get or give someone money in exchange for money of a different type
column7: Could you change a £20 note for two tens, please?^I need to change my dollars for/into pounds.
column8: Can I change money for US dollars there? (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

column6: used as a more polite form of 'can' when asking someone to provide something or do something
column7: Could you lend me £5?^Could you turn the music down a little, please?
column8: Could you please send it? (Key English Test; A2; French)

column6: something that you have to do because it is part of your job, or something that you feel is the right thing to do
column7: I felt it was my duty to tell them the truth.^He only went to see her out of duty.
column8: It is not enjoyable if you look at it as a duty. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

column6: to express an idea or plan for someone to consider
column7: I suggest (that) we wait a while before we make any firm decisions.^Liz suggested (that) I try the shop on Mill Road.^He suggested having the meeting at his house.
column8: I also suggest you should go to the Alps because there [is] a lot of beautiful scenery and if it's winter there are many place[s] to ski. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

column6: the job or series of jobs that you do during your working life, especially if you continue to get better jobs and earn more money
column7: He hasn't yet chosen a career.^a successful career in marketing^What are the career prospects?
column8: I think it's important to learn English for my career in the future. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

column6: a difficult situation that makes you feel worried or unhappy
column7: She's got a lot of pressure on her at work just now.^Be nice to him - he's been under a lot of pressure recently.^Can you work well under pressure?^the pressures of work
column8: I have two younger sisters so I think I can cope with the pressure [of] helping out in the summer camps. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

column6: not hard or firm
column7: soft ground^a soft pillow^soft cheese^I like chocolates with soft centres.
column8: It's a small pillow. Oh, it's so soft and I never sleep without it. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

column6: a bicycle
column7: He was on his bike.^My youngest child is learning to ride a bike.^We could go there by bike.
column8: We can go for a walk, ride a bike, [or] play football and other sports. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

column6: on the other side of
column7: There's a pub over the road we could go to.^The story continues over the page.^ The station is over the bridge.
column8: He apologised for the trouble and when he heard that they just wanted to stay over the weekend, he said they should go and buy the most important things and enjoy the weekend as the suitcase wo[uld]n't arrive until Monday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

column6: the main person in a film or play
column7: She plays the lead in both films.
column8: A child who leaves school feeling that he has succeeded in leaving his mark by holding the school record for high jump or getting the lead in the school production is a happy, confident child who is able to face the next chapter in his life knowing he can and will do well. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

column6: to tell someone about something
column7: If he calls me again, I shall inform the police.^I informed my boss that I was going to be away next week.
column8: This letter is to inform you that I will not be able to attend tomorrow's class due to medical issues. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

column6: badly or severely
column7: seriously ill/worried^He wasn't seriously injured - he just got a few cuts and bruises.
column8: She is seriously ill with cancer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai)

column6: to refuse to accept someone for a job, course, etc.
column7: She applied to Cambridge University but was rejected. ^He applied for a job as a chef, but he was rejected.
column8: [S]he rejected the proposal for a long, long time, [but] she finally married the Crown Prince 6 years ago. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

column6: introduces an idea that you have just thought of, or something that you have just remembered
column7: Oh, I've just thought of a problem.^Oh, and don't forget to lock the back door.^Oh yeah, someone phoned for you while you were out.
column8: Oh, and don't forget to show up in old clothes, ok? (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

column6: someone who does something brave or good, which people respect or admire them for
column7: a war hero^He became a national hero for his part in the revolution.^They consider her a hero.^Graham says he'll take my parents to the airport at four o'clock in the morning - what a hero!
column8: I couldn't believe it and while I was wondering if this was a dream, Mike Skinner, my hero, appeared and instantly started chatting with me as if we had been friends for years. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

column6: in a state as though you are sleeping, for example because you have been hit on the head
column7: She was hit on the head by a stone and knocked unconscious.
column8: In the morning, Mrs Crozier went to visit Miss Appleford in number 42 only to find her lying on the floor unconscious. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

column6: very fast movement
column7: I get a real thrill from speed.^He put on a sudden burst of speed.^Both cars were travelling at speed when the accident happened.
column8: Every summer I go to watersports because I like water. I'm very good at swimming and I like the speed of some watersports. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

column6: to be a big enough amount or of a good enough quality for something
column7: We couldn't find a house that met our needs/requirements.^ This old building will never meet the new fire regulations.
column8: Finally, as regards the Internet centre only two computers were available, which did not meet the needs of a Museum like this. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

column6: a large, strong military vehicle with a gun on it which moves on wheels inside large metal belts
column7: Tanks rolled into the city at dawn.
column8: They were inside the university and they were transmit[t]ing [o]n a radio frequency when the tanks invaded from the main entrance. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

column6: the people who do a type of work considered as a group
column7: The medical profession has expressed concern about the new drug.
column8: One day, [when] I had an exam, the examiner asked me questions about the legal profession. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

column6: to cover or surround something with paper, cloth or other material
column7: She wrapped the present and tied it with ribbon.^Wrap the chicken in foil and cook it for two hours.

column6: into an area or space from the outside of it
column7: Could you bring the clothes in for me?^Cut the pastry into a square and turn in the corners.
column8: First I brought in the big cake that my father had [bought]. (Key English Test; A2; Farsi)

column6: not hurt or ill
column7: Harry's just slipped on the ice. "Oh dear! Is he all right?"^She was very ill for a while but she's all right now.
column8: Hi Jo How are you? I hope you are all right. (Key English Test; A2; Arabic)

column6: to think of an idea or plan
column7: The original idea for the novel was conceived in Rome.
column8: I wonder what kind of person conceived this terrible and ignorant idea. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

column6: the lowest part of something
column7: He stood at the bottom of the stairs and called up to me.^Extra information can be found at the bottom of the page.
column8: One of the most amazing places we visited was a small lake at the bottom of a huge mountain. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

column6: to write a piece of music
column7: Who composed the music for the film?
column8: I've been composing music on a computer for over five years and I have a lot of knowledge when it comes to hardware. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

column6: describes people who know each other very well and like each other a lot, or who see and talk to each other a lot
column7: Mira is one of my closest friends.^Her relationship isn't good with her father, but she's very close to her mother.^My brother and I have become much closer over the years.
column8: That night, we had just my family and some of my close friends. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

column6: activities to advertise something
column7: a sales promotion^ They're giving away free T-shirts as a special promotion. ^Obviously as sales manager he'll be very involved in the promotion and marketing of the product.
column8: There are different kinds of jobs people do during the festival, e.g. some organisational work, doing promotion for the different events or sell[ing] tickets for the concerts. (First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian)

column6: to look at something for a period of time
column7: I had dinner and watched TV for a couple of hours.^I watched him get into a taxi.^I got the feeling I was being watched.^I sit by the window and watch people walking past.
column8: She works at the Glade and she watches television at night. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

column6: to remove things from a vehicle
column7: Can you help me unload the car?
column8: We began to unload the car and showed the children around the house. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)
